title: How Liverpool Champions League dreams ( literally ) slipped away
body_text:
For a game that so many smart people think so hard about, sometimes football can be pure dumb slapstick.
Two clubs can have brilliant coaching staffs and a whole tech start-upâ€™s worth of data scientists scanning the world to sign the gameâ€™s best players, and still a game, a season, even an entire era might come down to one slippery question: which famous professional athletes will fall down for no particular reason in incredibly embarrassing ways?

Smart tactical analysts could tell you a story about why this game happened the way it did. They could diagram how Liverpool overloaded the right wing with practised triangle rotations while Real Madrid returned the favour by pulling Karim Benzema wide left to create space for Vinicius Juniorâ€™s flamethrower dribbling at the other end. They could run film on how both teams scored goals by recognizing pressing triggers and jumping a line to cut off goalkeepersâ€™ passing lanes with their cover shadows or whatever.
This would all be fine and correct. It would also completely miss the point.
The story of the game â€” the real story, the one that mattered â€” was that people just kept slipping all over the place.
It started 90 seconds in, when Cody Gakpo pressured Eduardo Camavinga into coughing up the ball at the corner of Madridâ€™s box. Gakpo had a chance to put Mohamed Salah in on goal, but before he could play the pass his feet mysteriously flew out from under him like heâ€™d been slide tackled by Tyler Durdenâ€¦
The 14th minute was a whole Yakety Sax soloâ€™s worth of hijinks as first Jordan Henderson, then Camavinga and finally Thibaut Courtois all slipped and fell in one 10-second sequence to gift Liverpool a 2-0 goal that even Jurgen Klopp called â€œslapstickâ€.

Fabinho had to shift over to cover for his fallen teammate, leaving Camavinga wide open in midfield to hit a comfortable switch to Vinicius Jr, who dribbled into the box and scored the kind of mind-melting golazo that makes you forget all about some guy falling down 15 seconds earlier.

A few minutes later, Real Madrid narrowly avoided catastrophe as Eder Militao almost faceplanted on a goal kick with Darwin Nunez lurkingâ€¦
â€¦ and then narrowly missed out on glory when Vini went skates-up trying to recreate the curled shot from his first goalâ€¦
The ground looked a little firmer after halftime â€” maybe the players changed boots? Perhaps the grass dried out? But by that time, the matchâ€™s chaotic energy had long since slipped the surly bonds of Earth and touched the face of God.
So even though it almost didnâ€™t matter by that point, it felt fitting that Madridâ€™s last goal of an incredible five-nil run came when Alisson charged out to stop Benzema, couldnâ€™t quite decide which way to go, and slid helplessly to the ground. It was just that kind of day.
Gravity always seems to tug a little harder at Anfield, where the spectre of Steven Gerrard still stalks the pitch. Pep Guardiola drew heat last week for mentioning Gerrardâ€™s title-deciding 2014 slip in an interview, but in the same breath he brought up a Mario Balotelli fall that had worked out luckily for City. The point was: slip happens. What can you do?
One option in the face of footballâ€™s basic randomness is to try to outsmart it, to master every little detail and search out every last edge. Thatâ€™s the approach this modern version of Liverpool are famous for. Even the Anfield playing surface that was giving players fits is the most sophisticated grass-turf hybrid that money can buy.
â€œThat pitch is as finely tuned as the athletes who play on it,â€ one groundskeeping expert told The Athletic. â€œTests are done regularly and everything is data-driven.â€
He was talking about grass. The grass is data-driven.

Another option is to be like Carlo Ancelotti, who never sweats the small stuff. â€œFortunately,â€ the Real Madrid manager said, â€œas always happens with our team â€” or quite often happens, anyway â€” we kept our heads and gradually got ourselves back into the game.â€ Maybe itâ€™s easier to embrace chaos when it always seems to work in your brilliant playersâ€™ favour.
Over at Kloppâ€™s post-game presser, he was trying to avoid making excuses. â€œMost of the time, players didnâ€™t slip,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t know exactly why a few players slipped. We will speak about that.â€
But to point out that players spent their Tuesday night falling down more often than a Chumbawamba song isnâ€™t to say that Liverpool were good (after a dominant first half hour, they werenâ€™t) or Real Madrid bad (they were often brilliant). The slips worked for and against both teams.
Apart from the scoreline, it was a pretty even match.
The point is just that the concepts of â€œgoodâ€ and â€œbadâ€ donâ€™t always matter in football, a sport where players do a lot of smart, skilful, athletic stuff, and sometimes the ball goes in the net, and those two things are only occasionally related.
Liverpool werenâ€™t exactly graceful, but this game wasnâ€™t the catastrophe it will be made out to be. Look past the scoreline and there were positives to take away: a rejuvenated right-side triangle with Jordan Henderson back in his favourite spot; some bright moments from the young newcomers Nunez, Gakpo and Bajcetic.
FiveThirtyEightâ€™s team strength model ran the underlying numbers on this disaster and decided Liverpool are actually a little better than it thought. Bookies still give the club implied odds of about 40 per cent to squeak into the Premier Leagueâ€™s top four. Their season isnâ€™t over yet.
But in the Champions League? Yeah, Liverpool are probably down for the count. Year after year, knockout round after knockout round, everyone else slips away and Real Madrid are still standing.
